NEIGHBORHOODS WITHIN NEIGHBORHOODS I was at an interview this afternoon and while waiting in the reception area, began reading the following book which was on the coffee table: urlLink "Neighborhoods Within Neighborhoods" , published by the Rogers Park/West Ridge Historical Society. I found it fascinating, having lived in that area from 1995-1998. Having lived in Chicago since 1995, my outsider’s view is it’s the most segregated city I’ve ever experienced. Roger’s Park, however, is an eclectic mix of races, political stances and tolerance – more so than almost any town in the United States. During my “tenure” there, I met a jazz guitarist signed to Blue Note Records, a recovering alcoholic thrilled with his new life as a highly-trained pipefitter, another recovering alcoholic who worked as a bartender (of all things!), an aspiring Alderman, a female folk singer, a lesbian couple, a café owner once arrested during the 1968 Chicago Democratic Convention riots, a publicist for Alligator Records (an esteemed Chicago Blues label), as well as artists, Dead Heads, and students from Loyola University. (Even Shecky Green grew up here!) I didn’t realized how diverse the area was until I moved away. One of the annual highlights I enjoyed is Rogers Park's “Artists of the Wall” competition; wall-painting on a lakefront retaining wall. It seems that Rogers Park was once a staid, conservative "Leave It To Beaver" community which has gentrified into a counter-cultural community. I guess I'd always sensed that but the pictures in this book were amazing... charting the progression from 1940's life (high school kids at the prom, WWII drives) into photos of recent activism in the community. Upon my departure from Rogers Park to the Gold Coast, I'd experienced first hand the changes that Section 8 housing had on my block and was ready to leave. I now feel somewhat remorseful for not paying more attention to the uniqueness of the diversified population that surrounded me while I lived there. To be honest, living in the Gold Coast, while it's convenient and offers me many amenities, lacks the cultural urlLink diversity that I enjoyed in Rogers Park. It's so sterile here that I almost want to puke sometimes! The only real "flava" here is Mary Charming Crazy Woman who is usually found sprawled on the sidewalk outside the Walgreen's, shouting "C*NT!" to each woman who passes by, and the entertainment afforded by the "Streetwise" newspaper vendor stationed outside of each establishment in the area. FROM "USA TODAY", TODAY Web logs convey 'raw stuff' of war He calls himself Salam Pax and says he's a 29-year-old architect living in Baghdad. Nobody seems to know his true name, and some wonder whether he's a real person. But thousands have been reading his Web log on the Internet since war approached. ''Last night was very quiet in Baghdad,'' he wrote on Friday as bombers approached. ''The streets are empty, only bakeries are open and some grocery shops charging 4 times the normal prices.'' And later: ''On BBC we are watching scenes of Iraqis surrendering. My youngest cousin was muttering 'what shame' to himself. Yes, it is better for them to do that, but still, seeing them carrying that white flag makes something deep inside you cringe.'' Readers keep coming back to Pax because, after following his journal (dear_raed.blogspot.com), they have come to care about him. Pax is among the vast numbers of self-styled chroniclers who keep Web logs -- known on the Net as ''blogs.'' A blog can be written by one person or many, but the common denominator is their diary style, and the fact that when they're updated (sometimes several times a day) the newest entries appear at the top. This gives blogs a feeling of being both personal and immediate. It is impossible to say precisely how many active blogs are on the Net, but it's probably hundreds of thousands, says Michael Gartenberg, research director with Jupiter Research in New York. Born in the geeky corners of the Internet in the late '90s, blogs are coming of age, becoming an integral part of the Internet landscape. That is especially true now, during wartime. ''Reporters have an unparalleled ability to gather information,'' but blogs have the ability to convey unedited, raw personal drama as the war unfolds, says Diane, a New York blogger (gotham.realwomenonline.com) who has developed an e-mail friendship with Pax and is convinced he's real. (Like many bloggers, she does not use her full name.) ''Nothing really beats this raw stuff of life: What does bread cost? Where did you go to get it?'' says Diane, who supports the war but is worried about her friend. ''When the whole (war) thing started, it was like fireworks far away,'' she says. But Pax's blog has changed her perspective. ''It's strange to be in favor of a bombing campaign that could kill this guy.'' Personal stories are only part of the ''blogosphere,'' as some call the universe of Web logs. Sites such as Warblogs:cc (www.warblogs.cc) compile headlines from mainstream news sources and blogs, pointing people to stories from sources as diverse as CNN and The New York Times to Turkish newspaper Hurriyet and KurdishMedia.com. Warblogging.com, which posts links to news stories and commentaries, reports that it was getting 3,000 to 6,000 visitors a day before the war. But when war began, it says, the site was registering tens of thousands of visitors from all over the world, including the U.S. House of Representatives, the Department of Defense (news - web sites), the British House of Commons and the government of Syria. Web logger Anna Brosovic, a computer system administrator and part-time college student in Arlington, Texas, instinctively turned to blogs when the hostilities broke out. ''I have a lot less trust in the major media outlets in this country than I do foreign media outlets or bloggers,'' says Brosovic, 29, who writes a blog called Annatopia. Others are turning to blogs kept by war correspondents, such as CNN correspondent Kevin Sites and several BBC reporters. ECZEMA, PSORIASIS, LIVER SPOTS, WRINKLES!! Office Culture There is a running theme in virtually every office in Corporate America… an abundance of sugary treats, Krispy Crème Mondays, Bagel Wednesdays, leftover food from meetings (and, of course, the requisite several out-of-shape individuals who are the first ones to come back for seconds and thirds with a guilty, “oh, I really shouldn’t!” look on their faces.) However, the most annoying of all office trends are those co-workers who solicit money for various charities, environmental causes or supplemental income via their home business (in my office, one lady personalizes baby books for newborns, which she prints and binds at home – she keeps a stack of them prominently displayed on her desk). When someone posts an order form on the kitchen bulletin board selling Girl Scout Cookies for their daughter’s Brownie troop, comes around to my desk imploring me to buy a chocolate bar to support their son’s trip to a soccer playoff in some suburb far, far away, or asks for sponsors for their upcoming MS/Diabetes/Breast Cancer/Animal Shelter Walk-A-Thon, I usually humor them (more out of guilt than any real interest in saving, say, the Spotted Wood Owl in Washington State). I admit I do love those Thin Mints (especially after putting them in the freezer!) I thought I’d seen it all until I received this email from another office mate this afternoon: Sent: Thursday, April 24, 2003 4:05 PM Subject: Eczema, Psoriasis, Liver Spots, WRINKLES If you know anyone that has any of the above conditions, let me know. I have a great new product (been on the market for less than a week!) that is very reasonably priced for my "family" (50% discount) and has drastically improved/reduced the symptoms of eczema, psoriasis & liver spots as well as bug bites (?) and acne/pimples...oh yeah - it works great for wrinkles too! I have samples if anyone's interested! Thanks! “Michelle” (* not her real name) Now, if I was so unfortunate as to suffer from any of the above afflictions, I wouldn’t be much inclined to share that information with someone at work (especially a woman!) I could say I’d like a sample for “a friend” but you know how women love to gossip! Well, I'd make one exception to my rule -- I have a raging case of foot odor that seems incurable. If Michelle's product could cure that, I'd be willing to try anything. LinktoComments(' ') urlLink ">Comment

I HATE OVERTIME! I had to work late tonight. Until 9pm. They have scheduled overtime at this new job at The Unsuspecting Company, and I thought I'd be okay with it. I'm not. The consultants there (and executive assistants) frequently work until 10pm at least 3 nights per week. Most of the EA's here look so... haggard! This is supposed to be justified by time and a half salary (I could make some good money). They also schedule overtime on weekends. The irony is that they were going to offer me a $7 thousand dollars per year cut in my base salary, justifying the overtime as filling in the gap. I was able to get them to offer my previous job's base salary, but still, I don't like it. I'd packed my gym bag for a workout after work (assumed I'd get off by 7pm). My workouts mean a lot to me, almost as much as the $4,000 a year in overtime pay. I'm trying to keep focused on the money, as it is a way to pay for graduate school so I can finally leave being a secretary behind. It's hard, though.... It was weird getting out of the office when it was dark out, especially since today was so beautiful. I could have done my lower body workout in 30 minutes, then gone for a nice run through Lincoln Park while it was still light out. Ah, what am I saying? This is only temporary! However, my first thought as I hailed a cab at 9pm was "I shouldn't have to be doing this anymore." I want a normal 9 to 5 job, and a family to come home to. Some of our female consultants are over age 40, married with kids, and they put in long hours. That's not for me. I imagine their kids saying, "When's mommy coming home? Will she be home in time to read me a story and tuck me into bed?" I don't want to be a mom who works until 9pm. At least not on a regular basis, like these gals (and guys) do. True, they make tons of bank but at what cost??? I imagine a nice job at a small firm, then home at a reasonable hour that affords me time to go to the gym, then home for dinner and a walk through the park, then some t.v. Sounds boring but my life has been a roller coaster ride for so long. I long for some stabililty and something more predictable. In the meantime, I've been sending my resume out to jobs I've seen posted on Monster.com and HotJobs.com because there are positions out there (I hope) where I can make a decent living without messing up my sleep schedule (and bosses who have a pulse, unlike the bloated, red-faced mysogynist who's my new boss. Yuck! He's such a drip!). LinktoComments(' ') urlLink ">Comment

Carmen is the executive assistant to the gentleman in San Francisco whom my boss wished to speak with. SATURDAY NIGHT: I SHOULD HAVE STAYED HOME AND WATCHED T.V. Last night, I went to a private party held for the players of next week's Baseball All Star Game in Chicago, sponsored by Maxim and Harrah's Casino. My neighbor, Sonia, took me as her guest. I was very excited, not because I'm a baseball fan but because I thought it would be a great opportunity to people-watch (and who knows, I might meet someone interesting!) To be honest, I probably wouldn't have recognized Sammy Sosa. I would, however, recognize Barry Bonds because he went to the same college as I (Arizona State University) and lived next door to me, and when we were freshmen, we were friends. I even bought new shoes for the occasion (at Aldo, and 50% off!) We arrived at the Park West Theatre at approximately 9:00 p.m. and discovered that this "private party" wasn't that exclusive at all. There were thousands of people there of all types. Yes, there were the requisite Maxim Girls resplendent in their low-rise pants and tight t-shirts, as well as wanna be models; however, the majority of those attending were average-looking overweight suburbanites with huge glasses and fraternity boy types with Docker slacks and blue button-down shirts who looked like they'd just gotten off work. One particular woman struck my fancy with her back tat: Here's a photo of the "exclusive" party: Macy Gray was supposed to perform, so Sonia and I nursed watered-down gin & tonics, waiting for something to happen. At around 10:00 p.m., we sat down at a table occupied by two men in their late 20's. Sonia immediately struck up a dialogue with Drunk Boy and, for whatever reason, gave him her business card. Apparently, he said something offensive and she immediately took her card back. He must have said something redeeming so, after perusing his driver's license, she continued her conversation with him. I guess they must have had something in common because before I knew it, he had his hand on her ass. Well, by 11:00 p.m., we learned from a promoter that Macy Gray had cancelled her appearance several weeks ago but since the invitations had already been printed, they neglected to inform anyone. The promoter in question took a liking to me and stuck to me like glue for the next hour. Why oh why am I such a geek magnet????? Finally tiring of this lame party, Sonia and I (Drunk Boy and friend in tow) decided to blow this lame event but not before a photo opportunity on the red carpet outside the venue, set up for the non-existant ball players and celebrities. Please! No paparazzi! We moved on to Domaine and proceeded to anesthetize ourselves with more gin and tonics. Domain is a Chicago scenester hangout, and I got my fill of people-watching (whilst Sonia bonded with Drunk Boy). I went to the ladies' loo and met the Hilton Sisters. One of the girls was wearing a top resembling a hankerchief which reminded me of J-Lo's infamous Versace dress. "How do you keep that thing in place?" I asked. Hilton Sister #1: "Well, we're nurses..." Hilton Sister #2: "...and she used nursing tape! Giggle!" Wendy: "Nursing tape? Outstanding! May I take a picture of the two of you?" Hilton Sisters (in unison): "Sure! Are you with Chicago Magazine?" Wendy: "Uh, yeah."

In states of inactivity, I become lethargic, depressed, sarcastic and bitchy which for even my closest friends, makes me practically intolerable to be around (even for myself!) I haven't had an original thought in many months, hence, my numerous postings about Boris the Spider who resides outside my window. I was thinking about Boris tonight as she and her babies came out to play. What kind of spider is she? If she bites me, will I die a horrible death? How did she manage to find her way up so high, to the 17th floor of my building? Who invented liquid soap and why? The exterminator came the other day and said she is a harmless Brown Spider and that she blew up here on the wind. I decided to search online for more information (because I'm bored, as I said in my previous paragraph.) Feel free to surf to another Blog Site if my current state of apathy fatigues you (I recommend urlLink Mark's site and his recent "The Art of..." series of posts for something completely different). Otherwise, here is what I discovered about my Spiders in Residence: • One female may produce as many as 3,000 eggs in a series of several sacs over a period of time. Eggs may hatch a few weeks later (three weeks or the following spring) and reach adulthood in one year. • Females are fertilized several times during a lifetime with up to nine egg sacs, each containing 200 or more eggs. Young hatch in about eight days, staying within the sac until after the first molt. They are cannibalistic, eating one another. • Some spiderlings sail through the air (ballooning) on wind currents. Young spiders climb to a high point and release silk strands until the drag from the wind is sufficient to support their weight. Then, they release their hold and sail away, often for considerable distances. These ballooning threads (gossamer) can fill the air on clear days as spiderlings disperse to new areas. I learned that Boris is either of the species Neoscona Oaxacensis or Theridion sp. Here are pictures for comparison. What do you think? Boris Neoscona Oaxacensis Theridion sp. Okay, this isn't comforting me any.

NOT INTO HALLOWEEN BUT... I'm not a big fan of Halloween. I never liked all of the candy-eating, or the pressure to come up with an elaborate and creative costume. However, I do enjoy watching others observe this throwaway "holiday". If I was to dress up this year, I suppose I would have costumed myself as Kelly Osborne because I'm feeling kind of bloated right now. Last night while walking home from work, I happened to notice that the proprietor of a local restaurant decided to dress up his establishment for the occasion. It was already dark out when I happened upon Biggs Steakhouse. I was drawn by the colorful lights that illuminated the old mansion, and the fairy lights strung on the branches of the grand old oak tree that graces the front of the property. I stood on the corner across the street and began snapping pictures (with my digital camera which I always have with me at all times.) Suddenly, I heard a voice say, "So, how did the picture come out?" I turned around and standing beside me was a shaggy-haired, craggy-faced man a handful of years older than I am. "I don't know, I haven't looked at them yet." I was a bit annoyed because I was in one of my "moods" and didn't feel much like conversing with anyone. I'll admit that I was rather abrupt. The man continued to stand there while I took a few more photos, and I looked sideways at him in annoyance. I really just wanted to be alone and take my pictures. I realized that I was being rude and asked, "Is that your restaurant?" He said that indeed it was, and that he'd just bought Biggs last year. "We began dressing it up today but we have more coffins arriving tomorrow in time for our Halloween party. My name is Louis." (Coffins?) He stuck out his hand and I shook it. Wendy: "Pleasure to meet you, Louis." Louis: "Do you live in the neighborhood?" Wendy: "Yes. I've lived here for four years but I've never been to your restaurant." Louis: "Well, you should really stop by some time. We have a wonderful wine cellar in the basement, a steakhouse on the second floor, and a hip-hop club on the third. Come by and ask for me... I'm here 24-seven." Wendy: "Why thank you, Louis. I certainly will!" Louis gave me his business card with his email address. I sent him the pictures I took last night. It's always nice to make contact with the proprietor of an upscale restaurant. Who knows what "perks" I may receive!

About everything and nothing, then closing our eyes and willing ourselves to get a tan in half an hour on that unstable rooftop overlooking the Sunset Strip and the Chateau Marmont, where John Belushi overdosed in 1979. Before I got it into my head that leaving California for Illinois would be a good move to make because I really wanted to marry a nice Jewish boy, and the Jewish boys in Hollywood were either assholes or gay (I lived in West Hollywood, after all, the largest gay community outside of Greenwich Village or San Francisco). It's 2003 going on 2004 and I'm still unmarried but all of my ex-boyfriends are. During the whole O.J. Simpson murder trial, my friend Julie S. used to come over to my apartment on Friday nights, bearing cheap merlot. She lived 1/2 a block away from the murder scene and grew tired of the t.v. station news helicopters hovering above her street, the tourists who camped out in front of O.J.'s ex-wife's condo at the end of the street expecting to see the long-since removed bodies, and the LAPD motorcycle cops stationed there, asking for Julie's identification each night as she attempted to turn right onto her street and into her driveway. I still have an old videotape I took of Julie, arriving at my apartment with an unopened but soon to be consumed wine bottle ... and I remember the night we went to see the Cirque de Soleil in Santa Monica in a big tent on the beach ... a few hours of stunning make-believe in order to remove ourselves from the reality we were living that was so unreal that no one outside of Los Angeles would ever believe it was actually occurring in our hometown, the City of Angels. I want to go back in time, to California circa June of 1995... before Jerry Garcia died and the Grateful Dead disbanded, and I'd never again take another road trip with my Deadhead friends up to San Francisco to delight in that scene. Before I flew to O'Hare, thinking (naively) that something better awaited me in Chicago (arriving here in the midst of an oppressive heat wave that killed nearly 300 souls, then a winter where my nostril hairs froze the moment I stepped outside). Before I'd had one last meal at Sushi on Sunset Blvd. and savored their specialty, spicy tuna rolls as fat as the joint I wished I'd smoked with urlLink Alex on Zuma Beach but never did. Jesus, I hate this cold weather and oppressive gloom! I don't care about the seismographic urlLink Richter Scale (my family and I survived a urlLink major earthquake in '94 and my grandparents, living in a small apartment in Northridge, the epicenter, managed to keep a sense of humor even though their home was demolished) or the prediction of California someday falling into the ocean... by the sea is where I want to be. RIGHT NOW. But ... is it true what they say, that you can never truly go home? What *is* "home", anyhow? Where the heart is? "SECRET SANTAS" OF DAYS OF YORE Last year at this time, I was working as an executive assistant at a large global asset management firm. The admin group decided to hold a Secret Santa party (for those of you not in the know, it's where you draw a name out of a hat and buy a gift of a value not to exceed more than $20 for the person whose name you selected). I was not the most popular executive assistant at this firm, mainly because I actually had a brain and could think for myself... I never joined the other blondes gathered 'round the water cooler on Thursday mornings discussing the previous night's episode of "The Bachelor". That, in and of itself (besides being the only brunette in the group), made me an instant outcast. Well, it so happened that the Secret Santa hat was positioned on the desk of the one girl in the admin pool who hated me the most. On several occasions, I watched the other assistants select a name from the hat, open the folded piece of paper, then put it back into the hat and choose another. I wasn't stupid, I knew they'd unwittingly selected my name! One woman, Evelyn, had been out of the office on vacation for a week. When she returned, there were only two slips of paper left in the hat... with my name and Evelyn's. Well Evelyn was one of those women who other women need to be wary of. She would be nice to my face then stab me in the back when I wasn't around. Again, I wasn't stupid... I was in the toilet stall one afternoon when she came into the loo with another woman and said disparaging things about me, unaware that I was in the bathroom. (Until that moment, I never knew that I was such a slut! To this day, I appreciate Evelyn's candor. It's saved me from a life of sin, selling my body to the night.) Back to the Secret Santa story: On December 16, 2002, the administrative group went out to lunch at a Greek restaurant and after we ate, we exchanged gifts. The presents ranged from cute hat and glove sets and fancy picture frames to body lotion and matching martini glasses. I was the last woman to open her gift. Evelyn presented me with a lovely, colorful gift bag with a fancy ribbon and silver tissue paper. I opened it with a smile in anticipation of something nice. Everyone laughed (at me and not with me) when I dug to the bottom of the gift bag and discovered this: a urlLink Chicago Transit Authority bus pass!! Damn, that was cold. (P.S. I still have the colorful gift bag... it's great for toting my lunch.)
They say that "everything happens for a reason." Wondering what that "reason" is and who "they" are...

IT'S NOT BONE FUSION! This evening after my spinning class, I stopped into my local grocery store to pick up a quick bite to eat (a frozen vegan Indian entree). Of course, there's no such thing as picking up anything quickly at this market, even if the store's nearly empty; it's typically takes, (at minimum) a half-hour to purchase so much as a bottle of water at this place, mainly due to the apathy of the slow-moving checkers and baggers. To combat the lack of humanity, the management recently installed six electronic self-service scanning stations. In line in front of me at one of the scanners was a middle-aged, petite woman wearing too much makeup, an ugly fur coat and a sense of entitlement. She probably thought she was a cute damsel in distress but failed to attract much attention or support with her subsequent temper tantrum and foot-stomping. Background: These new-fangled supermarket scanning machines, if you make the mistake of breathing on them the wrong way, will emit an electronic voice that informs you, "Unknown item in bagging area. Please remove this item." If one accidentally bumps one's knee or handbag against the so-called bagging area, the (female) voice chastises, "The last item you scanned is incorrect. Please remove this item from the bagging area." There's really nothing to be done in this instance other than wait for one of the slack-jawed, drooling, apathetic, disinterested and slow-moving human beans to reset the system (yes, the employees are actual beans -- inanimate, full of fiber and quite flatulant) . Although I, being a rocket scientist, managed to figure out the nuances and idiosyncrasies of the self-service scanning station in, like, less than a nanosecond (glad I went to college!), I'm not immune to receiving these admonishments from the machine's disembodied voice for so much as looking at it the wrong way. This evening, a petite woman in her late 40's was having a dialogue with the machine. "Shut up! Shut up! I heard you already, just shut up!" She scanned the same box of Kleenex over the scanner again and again which only caused it to blink and bleat in confusion. "Oh, shut the f*ck up already, I heard you the first time!" She was making quite a scene with her little hissy fit. Her histrionics, had I not been starving and wanting to get the hell out of the market, would have been quite amusing. To facilitate things, I began complaining in unison with the woman: "C'mon! C'mooooooooooon ! I'm only 21, please don't let me die waiting in this fucking line ! Jeez, it's just a computerized scanner , lady; it's not BONE FUSION !" (That didn't make her complete her transaction any faster but it sure was fun!)

BRA-LESS I laundered all of my exercise clothing this weekend. Because I work out an average of 6 days per week, I’ve invested in a lot of expensive technical gear manufactured with state-of-the-art fabrics which won’t shrink, fade or lose their elasticity after numerous wearing and washings. Which is why I was highly annoyed when I misplaced one of my favorite Pearl Izumi jog bras after doing my laundry last Friday night. I’d intended to wear it during a spin class on Saturday morning but when I awoke and couldn’t find it in my clean pile of neatly folded clothes, I went down to the laundry room to do a bit of detective work. Perhaps I’d left it in the washing machine, I thought. After some investigation, my Pearl Izumi was not in the obvious place I’d suspected. I was nearly in a panic because it’s my favorite bra: it’s white, has no seams (no chafing), thin straps that don’t show under any of my workout tops, and it cost the dear sum of $40 USD. I’ve owned it for three years and it’s retained its elasticity through all of my sweaty activities. On a hunch, I decided to look in the garbage can in the corner of the laundry room and lying there amongst the used, no-static drier sheets and lint, like an abandoned orphan, was my favorite jog bra, unceremoniously disposed of without so much as a note. Needless to say, I was more than a bit pissed off. I retrieved my bra and immediately stomped down three flights to the lobby, where I waved it in the face of Jimmy, my building’s engineer and janitor who was sitting at the front desk. Wendy: “Jimmy, tell me something… does there appear to be anything wrong with this?” Jimmy: (Looks at the bra with a blank stare, like I’d just presented him with a steaming pile of feces.) Wendy: “Does this bra look frayed or stained or in a general state of disrepair?” Jimmy: “Uh… no...” Wendy: “Then do you have any idea why someone might have tossed this expensive article of clothing into the laundry room’s trash can?” Jimmy: “Um, I found it between the driers and it looked like garbage to me…” Wendy: “Jimmy, I would never have put this into the drier. It would have shrunk. And why would you think it was trash?” Jimmy: (Silence. Vacant stare.) Shaking my head in disgust, I stuffed the bra into my workout bag and stomped out of the lobby. Now I know what’s happened to all my missing socks! They looked like TRASH, so Jimmy threw them away! Supposedly, there’s a lost-and-found box in the office of the building but now I know that our building’s janitors are too lazy to put left-behind laundry in the crate. Later that evening, I told my friends Woody and Todd about this incident and Woody laughed. “I actually FOUND that bra in one of the washing machines and put it on the folding table in the laundry room! I even asked Todd if he thought it might be yours! It wasn’t between the driers. Jimmy is full of crap.” Jesus, I live in a Confederacy of Dunces!! Feel free to share your similar Stupidity Stories with me by writing to me at 123 Confederacy Street, Dunces, Illinois, 12345.

MISTAKEN IDENTITY I was sitting at a bus stop after work last Tuesday evening, contemplating my grocery list for my trip to the market on my way home when suddenly, I sensed that someone was staring at me. I looked up and directly across the street, my attention was drawn to a skinny guy in a dirty t-shirt with a greasy mullet standing beside the bed of a pickup truck parked on LaSalle Street at rush hour. My eyes met his from across the street and he waved at me, emphatically, with a big, snaggle-toothed grin on his face. I thought, "Ohmigod, why am I always being courted by *these* kinds of men?" (and quickly looked back down at my grocery list) but when I pretended I hadn't noticed him, he waved frantically, winked and hooted at me. I turned to the "zoftig" woman with Rubenesque proportions sitting beside me on the bus stop bench and said, "Sometimes, I get so discouraged! Where have all the gentlemen gone??" She replied that occasionally, when she takes the train instead of the bus, she sees senior couples holding hands and wonders what it must be like to be married for so long and still be so much in love. Then I realized that perhaps this greasy, mullet-sporting guy was wolf-whistling at the woman beside me and not your's truly!! And I hoped that was the case, because every mis-matched sock has a worn-out but still-sturdy shoe (or so I've been told by my mother). And then I felt guilty for being so presumptuous.
